title: Poggio dei Pini
text:
Poggio dei Pini, literally “Pine Knoll” is a locality situated in south-west <a href="Sardinia">Sardinia</a>, about 15 km from <a href="Cagliari">Cagliari</a>, the island’s capital. It is a <a href="frazione">frazione</a> of the municipality <a href="Capoterra">Capoterra</a>.
The village, with about 2,000 inhabitants, is of a type unique in Sardinia, and unusual in Italy. It is not an ancient settlement; rather it was founded in the 1960s and 1970s when a group of people who loved nature and the countryside decided to make it their home. Gradually the infrastructure was developed and residents arrived. The community is organised as a <a href="cooperative">cooperative</a> which, it is said, has resulted in a higher standard of services that would otherwise have been expected.
Poggio dei Pini lies within a hollow formed by the mountainous arc of <a href="Monte%20Arrubiu">Monte Arrubiu</a>, <a href="Monte%20Santa%20Barbara">Monte Santa Barbara</a> and <a href="Monte%20Pauliara">Monte Pauliara</a>. The countryside, already attractive, was enhanced by planting a luxuriant pine wood around a small lake. The sea is some 4 km to the east; the beaches of <a href="Nora%2C%20Italy">Nora</a> (20 km) and <a href="Chia%2C%20Italy">Chia</a> (35 km) can be reached by the SS. 195. Nearby is the designated park and <a href="nature%20reserve">nature reserve</a>, the mountainous "Parco Del Sulcis" forest area, a popular location for walking, trekking and mountain biking.
Two eighteenth-century edifices stand out in this area: the churches of Santa Barbara and of San Girolamo (<a href="Saint%20Jerome">Saint Jerome</a>). The former is especially an object of devotion as, according to local legend, it was in this neighbourhood that <a href="Saint%20Barbara">Saint Barbara</a> was decapitated.
